How and why applications are added to Azure Active Directory - Microsoft identity platform | Microsoft Docs
How and why applications are added to Azure Active Directory - Microsoft identity platform | Microsoft Docs
Extract: You can manage <a href="app-objects-and-service-principals#application-object" data-linktype="relative-path">application objects</a> in the Azure portal through the <a href="https://aka.ms/appregistrations" data-linktype="external">App Registrations</a> experience. Application objects describe the application to Azure AD and can be considered the definition of the application, allowing the service to know how to issue tokens to the application based on its settings. The application object will only exist in its home directory, even if it's a multi-tenant application supporting service principals in other directories.
Entry: You can manage <a href="app-objects-and-service-principals#application-object" data-linktype="relative-path">application objects</a> in the Azure portal through the <a href="https://aka.ms/appregistrations" data-linktype="external">App Registrations</a> experience. Application objects describe the application to Azure AD and can be considered the definition of the application, allowing the service to know how to issue tokens to the application based on its settings. The application object will only exist in its home directory, even if it's a multi-tenant application supporting service principals in other directories.

Subject: How and why applications are added to Azure Active Directory - Microsoft identity platform | Microsoft Docs
Extract: For any given application, it can have at most one application object (which is registered in a "home" directory) and one or more service principal objects representing instances of the application in every directory in which it acts.
Entry: For any given application, it can have at most one application object (which is registered in a "home" directory) and one or more service principal objects representing instances of the application in every directory in which it acts.

Calling long-running Functions from Logic Apps - Jeff Hollan - Medium
Extract: <h1 id="ae62" class="hc hd du at as he hf hg hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp" data-selectable-paragraph="">Calling with polling � Durable Async Orchestrator</h1><p id="a559" class="ft fu du at fv b fw hq fy hr ga hs gc ht ge hu gg" data-selectable-paragraph="">The final option uses polling instead of webhook. This approach has the benefits of not requiring you to manage any queues, and you can use the built-in Azure Functions action from Logic Apps. This is achieved by leveraging <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-functions/durable-functions-overview#pattern-3-async-http-apis" class="bq fh hv hw hx hy" target="_blank" rel="noopener nofollow">Azure Durable Functions</a>.</p><p id="9676" class="ft fu du at fv b fw fx fy fz ga gb gc gd ge gf gg" data-selectable-paragraph="">In this approach, you invoke an HTTP Function which kicks off a durable orchestration. The durable orchestrator can now take on the work of managing function calls (that may take &gt; 2 minutes) and returning a status back to the logic app. When all work is completed, the durable function orchestrator will respond with a 200.</p><ol class=""><li id="895d" class="ft fu du at fv b fw fx fy fz ga gb gc gd ge gf gg ib ic id" data-selectable-paragraph="">Function A gets the request from Logic Apps</li><li id="9e9a" class="ft fu du at fv b fw ie fy if ga ig gc ih ge ii gg ib ic id" data-selectable-paragraph="">Function A invokes a durable orchestrator function and returns the status (202 Accepted with location header for status updates)</li><li id="cdd7" class="ft fu du at fv b fw ie fy if ga ig gc ih ge ii gg ib ic id" data-selectable-paragraph="">The durable orchestrator calls the function(s) that need to do work which may be &gt; 2 minutes</li><li id="0ac0" class="ft fu du at fv b fw ie fy if ga ig gc ih ge ii gg ib ic id" data-selectable-paragraph="">The Logic App will continue to check the location header (automatically) until a 200 status code is received and successful result</li></ol>
Entry: <h1 id="ae62" class="hc hd du at as he hf hg hh hi hj hk hl hm hn ho hp" data-selectable-paragraph="">Calling with polling � Durable Async Orchestrator</h1><p id="a559" class="ft fu du at fv b fw hq fy hr ga hs gc ht ge hu gg" data-selectable-paragraph="">The final option uses polling instead of webhook. This approach has the benefits of not requiring you to manage any queues, and you can use the built-in Azure Functions action from Logic Apps. This is achieved by leveraging <a href="https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-functions/durable-functions-overview#pattern-3-async-http-apis" class="bq fh hv hw hx hy" target="_blank" rel="noopener nofollow">Azure Durable Functions</a>.</p><p id="9676" class="ft fu du at fv b fw fx fy fz ga gb gc gd ge gf gg" data-selectable-paragraph="">In this approach, you invoke an HTTP Function which kicks off a durable orchestration. The durable orchestrator can now take on the work of managing function calls (that may take &gt; 2 minutes) and returning a status back to the logic app. When all work is completed, the durable function orchestrator will respond with a 200.</p><ol class=""><li id="895d" class="ft fu du at fv b fw fx fy fz ga gb gc gd ge gf gg ib ic id" data-selectable-paragraph="">Function A gets the request from Logic Apps</li><li id="9e9a" class="ft fu du at fv b fw ie fy if ga ig gc ih ge ii gg ib ic id" data-selectable-paragraph="">Function A invokes a durable orchestrator function and returns the status (202 Accepted with location header for status updates)</li><li id="cdd7" class="ft fu du at fv b fw ie fy if ga ig gc ih ge ii gg ib ic id" data-selectable-paragraph="">The durable orchestrator calls the function(s) that need to do work which may be &gt; 2 minutes</li><li id="0ac0" class="ft fu du at fv b fw ie fy if ga ig gc ih ge ii gg ib ic id" data-selectable-paragraph="">The Logic App will continue to check the location header (automatically) until a 200 status code is received and successful result</li></ol>

Subject: Calling long-running Functions from Logic Apps - Jeff Hollan - Medium
Extract: Azure Logic Apps and Azure Functions are a perfect pairing for Serverless. Azure Functions are serverless compute, while Logic Apps act as serverless workflows and integrations. However one challenge comes from the fact that Azure Functions can run for up to 10 minutes in the serverless �consumption� plan, but a single HTTP request from Logic Apps will time out after 2 minutes.
Entry: Azure Logic Apps and Azure Functions are a perfect pairing for Serverless. Azure Functions are serverless compute, while Logic Apps act as serverless workflows and integrations. However one challenge comes from the fact that Azure Functions can run for up to 10 minutes in the serverless �consumption� plan, but a single HTTP request from Logic Apps will time out after 2 minutes.

Subject: Calling long-running Functions from Logic Apps - Jeff Hollan - Medium
Extract: In this pattern, the Logic App will invoke the Function via the <strong class="fv hz">HTTP Webhook</strong> action <em class="ia">instead</em> of the Azure Function built-in action. This action will allow us to pass along a URL the Azure Function can POST to when the work has completed. A benefit of this approach is I can still have my function run for &gt; 2 minutes, <em class="ia">and</em> I can get the response back into the same workflow that invoked it.
Entry: In this pattern, the Logic App will invoke the Function via the <strong class="fv hz">HTTP Webhook</strong> action <em class="ia">instead</em> of the Azure Function built-in action. This action will allow us to pass along a URL the Azure Function can POST to when the work has completed. A benefit of this approach is I can still have my function run for &gt; 2 minutes, <em class="ia">and</em> I can get the response back into the same workflow that invoked it.

Subject: Which Microsoft Azure replication service should you use?
Extract: Finally, you have geo-redundant storage and read-access geo-redundant storage which replicates your data to a secondary region outside your primary region. Even if the entire region were for some reason to go down you would still have access to the data to be recovered in the other region which gives GRS at least 99.99999999999999% (16 9's) durability of objects over a given year. The difference between GRS and RA GRS is fairly simple, GRS only allows to be read in the secondary zone in the even of a failover from the primary to secondary while RA GRS allows the option to read in the secondary whenever.  It should be noted that your application and data will come with two endpoints with RA GRS requiring you to manage both endpoints.
Entry: Finally, you have geo-redundant storage and read-access geo-redundant storage which replicates your data to a secondary region outside your primary region. Even if the entire region were for some reason to go down you would still have access to the data to be recovered in the other region which gives GRS at least 99.99999999999999% (16 9's) durability of objects over a given year. The difference between GRS and RA GRS is fairly simple, GRS only allows to be read in the secondary zone in the even of a failover from the primary to secondary while RA GRS allows the option to read in the secondary whenever.  It should be noted that your application and data will come with two endpoints with RA GRS requiring you to manage both endpoints.

Subject: Azure DDoS Protection - Designing resilient solutions | Microsoft Docs
Extract:
For example, the risk of attack increases with the size (<em>surface area</em>) of the application. You can reduce the surface area by using whitelisting to close down the exposed IP address space and listening ports that are not needed on the load balancers (<a href="/en-us/azure/load-balancer/load-balancer-get-started-internet-portal" data-linktype="absolute-path">Azure Load Balancer</a> and <a href="/en-us/azure/application-gateway/application-gateway-create-probe-portal" data-linktype="absolute-path">Azure Application Gateway</a>). <a href="/en-us/azure/virtual-network/security-overview" data-linktype="absolute-path">Network security groups (NSGs)</a> are another way to reduce the attack surface.
You can use <a href="/en-us/azure/virtual-network/security-overview#service-tags" data-linktype="absolute-path">service tags</a> and <a href="/en-us/azure/virtual-network/security-overview#application-security-groups" data-linktype="absolute-path">application security groups</a> to minimize complexity for creating security rules and configuring network security, as a natural extension of an application�s structure.
Entry:
For example, the risk of attack increases with the size (<em>surface area</em>) of the application. You can reduce the surface area by using whitelisting to close down the exposed IP address space and listening ports that are not needed on the load balancers (<a href="/en-us/azure/load-balancer/load-balancer-get-started-internet-portal" data-linktype="absolute-path">Azure Load Balancer</a> and <a href="/en-us/azure/application-gateway/application-gateway-create-probe-portal" data-linktype="absolute-path">Azure Application Gateway</a>). <a href="/en-us/azure/virtual-network/security-overview" data-linktype="absolute-path">Network security groups (NSGs)</a> are another way to reduce the attack surface.
You can use <a href="/en-us/azure/virtual-network/security-overview#service-tags" data-linktype="absolute-path">service tags</a> and <a href="/en-us/azure/virtual-network/security-overview#application-security-groups" data-linktype="absolute-path">application security groups</a> to minimize complexity for creating security rules and configuring network security, as a natural extension of an application�s structure.

Subject: Run tasks in parallel to use compute resources efficiently - Azure Batch | Microsoft Docs
Extract: <strong>Mitigating node number limits</strong> when inter-node communication is required within a pool. Currently, pools configured for inter-node communication are limited to 50 compute nodes. If each node in such a pool is able to execute tasks in parallel, a greater number of tasks can be executed simultaneously.
Entry: <strong>Mitigating node number limits</strong> when inter-node communication is required within a pool. Currently, pools configured for inter-node communication are limited to 50 compute nodes. If each node in such a pool is able to execute tasks in parallel, a greater number of tasks can be executed simultaneously.

Subject: What is Azure Container Instances? - Azure Container Instances | Microsoft Docs
Extract:
<h2 id="virtual-network-deployment-preview">Virtual network deployment (preview)<a class="docon docon-link heading-anchor" href="#virtual-network-deployment-preview" aria-labelledby="virtual-network-deployment-preview"></a></h2>
<p>Currently in preview, this feature of Azure Container Instances enables <a href="container-instances-vnet" data-linktype="relative-path">deployment of container instances into an Azure virtual network</a>. By deploying container instances into a subnet within your virtual network, they can communicate securely with other resources in the virtual network, including those that are on premises (through <a href="../vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-vpngateways" data-linktype="relative-path">VPN gateway</a> or <a href="../expressroute/expressroute-introduction" data-linktype="relative-path">ExpressRoute</a>).</p>
Entry:
<h2 id="virtual-network-deployment-preview">Virtual network deployment (preview)<a class="docon docon-link heading-anchor" href="#virtual-network-deployment-preview" aria-labelledby="virtual-network-deployment-preview"></a></h2>
<p>Currently in preview, this feature of Azure Container Instances enables <a href="container-instances-vnet" data-linktype="relative-path">deployment of container instances into an Azure virtual network</a>. By deploying container instances into a subnet within your virtual network, they can communicate securely with other resources in the virtual network, including those that are on premises (through <a href="../vpn-gateway/vpn-gateway-about-vpngateways" data-linktype="relative-path">VPN gateway</a> or <a href="../expressroute/expressroute-introduction" data-linktype="relative-path">ExpressRoute</a>).</p>

Subject: Azure Container Instances container groups - Azure Container Instances | Microsoft Docs
Extract:
<h2 id="what-is-a-container-group">What is a container group?<a class="docon docon-link heading-anchor" href="#what-is-a-container-group" aria-labelledby="what-is-a-container-group"></a></h2>
<p>A container group is a collection of containers that get scheduled on the same host machine. The containers in a container group share a lifecycle, resources, local network, and storage volumes. It's similar in concept to a <em>pod</em> in <a href="https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/pods/pod/" data-linktype="external">Kubernetes</a>.</p>
Entry:
<h2 id="what-is-a-container-group">What is a container group?<a class="docon docon-link heading-anchor" href="#what-is-a-container-group" aria-labelledby="what-is-a-container-group"></a></h2>
<p>A container group is a collection of containers that get scheduled on the same host machine. The containers in a container group share a lifecycle, resources, local network, and storage volumes. It's similar in concept to a <em>pod</em> in <a href="https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/workloads/pods/pod/" data-linktype="external">Kubernetes</a>.</p>

Subject: Sub-orchestrations for Durable Functions - Azure | Microsoft Docs

Entry: Sub-orchestrator functions behave just like activity functions from the caller's perspective. They can return a value, throw an exception, and can be awaited by the parent orchestrator function.
